testimony: We may proceed with the application of Mr Solomon Collen Mtambo.
I thank you Madam Chair, he wishes to take the oath.
Mr Mtambo, will you please rise?  Are you going to take an oath?
You may sit down, you have been sworn in.  You may take over Mr Claassen.

Thank you Madam Chair.  Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, you are today an applicant before this Amnesty Committee concerning a crime which were committed on the 2nd of April 1994, the killing of Mshenga Phumayo, is that correct?
Sorry Mr Claassen, was the date not the 29th of May 1993?
Pardon me, that is indeed correct, that was the date of his conviction.
And Mr Mtambo, you were sentenced on the 2nd of April 1994 to a twelve year prison sentence, for this particular crime, which you are currently serving?
Yes, that is correct, but I was sentenced on the 13th of June 1995.

Pardon me, Madam Chair, let the record state then the date of sentence.
	Mr Mtambo, could you very briefly just explain to the Court the circumstances immediately surrounding the commission of this offence, what happened the day when you killed Mr Phumayo?

Yes, I can.   I was a Vice-Chairman of IFP youth at Dela in Davel.
	We used to hold meetings at a creche as the youth of Inkatha.  At Dela there were conflicts between the ANC and the IFP, and a decision was taken that some of us were not supposed to use certain streets, and some of us were not supposed to use other streets.
	Other members of the IFP were chased away if they were found in a certain street, which they were not supposed to use.  There were fights between IFP and ANC.
	I stayed there or we held a meeting at the creche with the youth, because I was their leader.  I took a decision, even though I didn't tell them about my decision, and my decision was solely based on how were we going to attack this problem or tackle this problem which we had.
	I took a decision to attack someone who was involved, his name is Phumayo.  I realised that if I shoot Mr Phumayo, it was going to enhance our organisation, because some members of the opposite organisation, which was ANC, were going to be scared and join the IFP.  Therefore I attacked him.
	I was scared after I killed him.  I didn't like what I did.
Mr Mtambo, could you just please tell us the day that you killed him, what exactly happened there?

On the day when I killed Mr Phumayo, I was at Maria Mthetwa's place.  I think it was approximately twenty past eight, to half past eight.  I saw him, he had a navy jacket and a powder blue trousers.  I saw him through a window.
	Duduza had already informed me that I should watch because he heard from the rumour that I was going to be attacked.  Since I had this information and also it was my plan that if I attacked Mr Phumayo, it was going to help us.  I saw him as I was sitting at Maria's place, and when he was next to an electric box, that is when I approached him and I greeted him.
	What I saw from his face, he got scared when I was near him and I took out my gun and I shot him.  That is what happened on that day.

Mr Mtambo, could you just clarify, you just now mentioned that you were inside Maria's house and you saw him next to an electric box.  Can you just tell us how this came to be, what happened from Maria's house, or was this in Maria's house, what happened there?
I was with Fanosi July Nkosi, July Mthetwa and Stella Nonqlandla.

Won't you just give these names slowly, we are taking down your evidence and try and give your evidence at a pace at which the Translators will be able to translate everything you say.  Just be a little slower as you give your evidence.
You may repeat the people you with at Maria's house.
July Mthetwa, Fanosi Nkosi, Nonqlandla Mthetwa, July's brother-in-law and July's sister, Mercy and Maria Mthetwa, the owner of the house.  I can't remember others who were there.
Are these people members of your organisation?
Were they present there at for any particular reason?

No, there was no particular reason, we were just sitting there inside the house.
	Most of the time, I used to visit Maria's place.

Many people who were members of IFP, used to visit Maria's place.  They used to just visit the place.  Most of the people who used to visit Maria's place, were IFP members, because even Maria herself, was an IFP member.
Do you recall that during your criminal trial, this place was described as a shibeen?
Was it not frequented by people in Davel?
It was, some people, the people that were from local and these people never used to give us the problem.
And it was frequented by people irrespective of any political affiliation?

Can I just clarify one thing, just before you go on Mr Claassen, sorry to do so.
	Who told you this person said, he told you that he had heard that you were going to be attacked and you must watch out?  I just didn't catch the name when you were testifying?
Don't explain or clarify anything, just answer the question.  He just asked you a question and that is fine, we've got the answer now.

Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, not who you were in the house with, you said that you saw the deceased at an electrical box.  Can you just very briefly, what happened from the house to the point where you shot him?

We were just sitting there and we were drinking and liquor was full on the table, on the 29th.  Because I have already made a decision as to gain IFP members, because we were the minority in that place, I didn't tell anyone about my decision because I realised that the people who were there, who were present at that house ...
May I interrupt Mr Claassen, we will also expect you to take charge of your client's evidence in chief please.
I will do so Madam Chair.

Please interrupt him if during his evidence, you can hear that it is not being translated the way you want it.  He is not responding to the question, to your question, because now he is giving evidence on an aspect that you have not put a question to, he is not responding to your question.
Thank you Madam Chair, I will do so.
May I then just address your client?

Mr Mtambo, we would request you to please confine your responses to questions being posed by your legal representative, and only confine your responses to those questions.
	The question which was put to you was to explain what happened from the time you recognised that Mr Phumayo was outside the electric box, what did you do because you explained that you went out, you got to him next to the electric box, you greeted him and then you shot him.
	Your Attorney wants you to explain in detail every step what you did, from the time that you left the house up to the time you greeted him and then shot him.
When I left the house, I turned behind the house, I took the gun from the bag.

What do you mean when you say you turned the house, maybe that has not been properly translated?
	If you can just please repeat what you have just said.
When I left the house, or when I came out from the house, I went behind the house, I took the gun from the bag and I cocked it.
Now what do you mean by saying that you took the gun from the - is it back or from a bag?
My apology there, the gun was in my pocket, in my trousers pocket, in my trousers pocket.
Yes, you may proceed Mr Mtambo.

I took the magazine, I put it in my left pocket.  I only had one bullet in that gun.  It was loaded inside the gun.
	I left Maria's house, I went straight to the deceased, Mr Mshenga.
Did I understand you to be saying you left Maria's house for the deceased's house, Mshenga, was that properly translated?

I went to Mshenga straight, not in his house, he was on the street, not in his house.
	When I arrived there, I greeted him.  He answered back and I asked him why he was there.  He said he was there, looking for his girlfriend.  I didn't trust what he said because I have already heard something.  That is when I took out the gun from my pocket.  He was facing downwards, and I shot him from the back and then I ran away.
Why didn't you believe him when he said he was there for his girlfriend?

He never used to frequent that street, and I didn't know that he had a girlfriend on that street.  This is why I didn't believe him.
	I didn't know whether he was telling the truth as to his being there because he wanted to see his girlfriend, or if he was there because of what I have already heard.
	When I shot him, I ran away.  I ran away, I passed Maria's house and I jumped the fence.   I got inside the yard, I opened the window, I got inside through the window.
Can I just get clarity on this please Mr Mtambo.  The street you shot him in, is this the same street Maria's house is in?
Yes, that is the same street.

You explained to us earlier on that there were streets that were to be used by IFP members and streets to be used by the ANC members.
	Was this an ANC or IFP street?
I will say it was an IFP street.  IFP members used to use that street frequent, more than the ANC.
And then the members who visited Maria's house, who were not IFP members, which street did they use?

The people who used to frequent Maria's place, they were neighbours, who were drinking and we used to take them as alcoholics.
	These are the people who used to frequent Maria's house.
Who were not IFP members, I just want clarity on that?

Most of them were IFP members who used to visit Maria's place, but those who were not affiliated with IFP, they were just alcoholics and neighbours.
	I can give an example and say ...
Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, you have just testified that you had heard something from this person Duduza and that made you mistrust the deceased.  Who is Duduza and what did he tell you?
That is correct, Duduza, what Duduza told me made me  mistrust or distrust  Phumayo?

The question was who is Duduza and what did he tell you, there are two questions.
	Who is Duduza Qaba and the second question is, what did he Duduza Qaba tell you?

Duduza Qaba, it is a member of the ANC, he was a member of the ANC and it is a female, I grew up with her.  We got along very well, and she got along well with Sophy, Ndono.
	They were friends with Sophy, Ndono.
Her name is Ndono, her mother is Sophy.
Sophy is my aunt and Ndono is my cousin.  Ndono is my niece.
Mr Mtambo, and what did this Duduza tell you?

He greeted me and he told me to be careful and when I asked him as to why should I be careful, he said I know about those people who were referred to as comrades, but he didn't give me the name of the person who was going to give me a problem, which he has already perceived.
Sorry, you are being very vague.  Please explain this, you are talking around.  Did she say that you know these people or maybe there is a problem with the translation, I am not sure.

He said I know the comrades, he said and I know the fact that we don't get along with the comrades and the enmity between the IFP and the ANC.
	I knew that he was there most of the time, in the township.

I think there was something wrong that probably you didn't say, you omitted to say or probably was omitted in the translation.  You seem to have mentioned somebody's name, but it was not translated.
	Can you repeat what you have just said so that we can get our notes corrected.  There is something missing in my note and I see there is also a nod from one of the Committee members, that he is also missing something.
I don't remember mentioning someone's name, I mentioned only Duduza.

Perhaps I can help here, what we are trying to understand is what exactly did she tell you?  Did she say to you I know these people, that she knows them, or did she say to you, be careful, you know these people, they are your enemies and make an implication that there was something you had to be careful about?  It is just not coming out clearly in the way either you are saying it, or it is being translated, so I want you just to try and give us the sense.
	Did she say she had heard something that you should worry about, or did she say you know these people, I have a feeling something might happen, etc?  That is what we are trying to understand.
He said to me, Stumu, you must be careful today.  That is what he said.
And then he used a certain name, which included comrades, what did he say about comrades?
I asked him why should I be careful, and he said you know that there is enmity between you and the comrades.

Did you try to ask him as to who exactly among the comrades you should be careful of or from?
	In your knowledge, the number of the comrades in Davel, were they a majority?
And in other words, he was warning you to be careful from all the comrades?
Mr Mtambo, did this Duduza mention the name of Mr Phumayo?
No, I can't remember whether he mentioned his name, but if I recall very well, I don't remember him mentioning his name.

You just said that she did not identify any person in particular.  That is the note I have here?
	Did she or did she not, or can't you remember?  These are two different things.

Just stick to the evidence you have already testified to.  You don't have to say you don't remember if you know that he didn't identify any person.
	You get a contradiction in the two things you are saying.

Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, just to get back, you started your evidence by saying that you were a member of the IFP.  At that stage, how long had you been a member, and what was your rank inside the IFP?
At first I was a Vice-Chairman of the IFP.  Mkhize left and then I was the Chairman.
Is it of the IFP or of the IFP Youth Brigade?
I just needed that clarification Mr Claassen, because this evidence has already been given by mr Mtambo, right in the beginning.  You don't need to traverse it again.
Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, can you just state how long had you been a member of the IFP?
When I first joined the IFP, was in 1992 up until now.
May I interpose Mr Claassen, whilst we are on this point, and for how long had you been the Vice-Chairperson of the Youth Brigade?
When were you first appointed as the Chair of the IFP Youth Brigade?

Can you approximate the month when you became such a Chair?  The incident occurred in May 1993, can you from there be able to estimate how long you had been in your position as the Chair of that organisation?
Thank you.  Thank you Mr Claassen.
Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, you also at the beginning briefly stated that  a meeting had been held in kwaDela where a certain decision was taken.  What was the nature of this meeting?
Do you mean the meeting which was held at the creche, are you referring to that meeting?
Won't you just make that clear to him, it will facilitate his response I think.
Mr Mtambo, with specific reference to the meeting, you said the meetings were held at a creche, that meeting at the creche.
We used to hold meetings and we were encouraging the youth of IFP and we were encouraging each other as to recruit other youth members, and the collection of money to help other members ...
Come to our rescue Mr Claassen and please try and take charge.
Certainly Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, was this specific meeting, an IFP meeting?
Do you remember or recollect who was present at this particular meeting?
Can you just briefly state who these people were?
I will mention some names, even though I cannot remember everyone who was present.
Mr Mtambo, I think we will leave it at that.  Can you approximate how many people were present at this particular meeting?
And were these people all IFP members?
Mr Mtambo, you mentioned that a decision was taken, what was this decision?
Didn't he say he took a decision?  That is his evidence, are you not trying to change his evidence Mr Claassen?
My pardon Madam Chair, it is indeed that he said the decision was taken by him.

Maybe you can just clear that with him, but he has already testified to him taking a decision, not to people who were at that meeting taking a decision.
	Maybe you need to get clarity on that.

As the Court pleases.  If I may approach him just for a second.  Thank you Madam Chair.
	Thank you Madam Chair, it is indeed correct as stated, the decision was taken by him.
	Mr Mtambo, could you just briefly explain the decision and why it was taken?
Because of the harassment or torture, I was injured before I took this decision.

I was walking one day, and I was beaten up and I opened a case, but then it was never followed up.
	After I got injured, my teeth were loosened.
Mr Mtambo, do you know who these people were that beat you up?
Were they IFP members, were they ANC members?
Mr Mtambo, did you know the deceased?
He was a member of an ANC organisation.
I used to see him when they were toyi-toying, he was right in front.
Do you know if the deceased held any specific position within the ANC?
If you say a Chairman,  a Chairman of the local branch or what kind of a Chairman?
He was a Chairman of the Youth Brigade.
Mr Mtambo, why did you decide to kill Mr Phumayo?
He was a brave man.  He used to attack IFP members and he used to make sure that he injured them.
Mr Mtambo, what were the circumstances like in kwaDela prior to this incident?
There were conflicts and people were fighting.
Were these conflicts of a political nature?
Yes, it was between ANC and IFP.
Mr Mtambo, you said you made this decision.  In what capacity did you decide this, as Chairman of the IFP Youth Brigade?
I took this decision as a Chairman of the IFP Youth Brigade.
Mr Mtambo, once you had committed this act, was there any gain for you personally for doing this?
What did you hope to gain politically?
My aim was to gain more members because I knew that other people were going to be scared and they were going to join the IFP.

Come again, I didn't get that.  You killed him because you thought other people would be scared and would join the IFP?  By other people, do you mean the ANC people will then be intimidated and leave the organisation and join your organisation?

Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, Madam Chair, if I may, I would just like to draw your attention to the applications which you brought before this Commission.
	If I may Madam Chair, it is page 2 and 7 respectively.  Mr Mtambo, it is pointed out to you that you brought two or submitted two Form 1's, applications, which are included in your application form today, is that correct?

Madam Chair, if I may refer to page 3, paragraph (b) just under number 4, the question Mr Mtambo was put to you state whether any person was injured, killed or suffered any damage to property as a result of such acts or omissions or offences.
	You had written down deceased Mshenga Phumayo and six houses were set on fire, would you care to explain that?
Yes.  After I shot Mr Phumayo, houses were burnt.  It was after this incident.
Mr Mtambo, could you just clarify, you are talking about houses, who burnt down these houses?
ANC burnt the houses.  Now I cannot say who exactly, because I was hiding at the time.
Can we get clarity on when these houses were burnt?
On the 29th of May, on the same day when I killed Mr Phumayo.  After I killed him, then the houses were burnt down.
What time did you kill Mr Phumayo?
I can say it was half past eight or approximately, or between half past eight to nine o'clock.
And what time were these houses burnt down?
It was after a while.  If I can just estimate, I will just say between ten and eleven o'clock, I don't have the exact time.
And to whom did they belong?
Were these high ranking members of the IFP?
No, they were just ordinary people who were known to be members of the IFP.
Thank you Mr Claassen, you may proceed.

Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mtambo, I also wish to draw your attention to page 18 of the application bundle.

	Can you briefly tell the Commission what the circumstances surrounding when you made this affidavit, why you said the things that you did?
I would like to ask as to which statement are you referring to, you are talking about my application or my statement?
If I may Madam Chair, the confession statement taken at the Davel police station.

Yes, I can explain.  I made a statement in the police, and I didn't tell the truth, it was a lie.
	I was trying to escape from being sentenced for what I had done.
Mr Mtambo, can you just tell the Commission what do you, how do you feel today about these offences?

I am not relieved at all.  I am not at rest for what I have done.
	I am deeply sorry, more especially when we mention the deceased's name.

Thank you Madam Chair, I have no further questions for the applicant.

Ms Thabete, do you have any questions to put to Mr Mtambo?
Yes Madam Chair, I do but before I proceed, I would like to put it on record, that I have met with the victims and I will be representing them as well.
Mr Mtambo, you have testified that there was a lot of political conflict at your area.  During what period was this?
From when I joined the IFP, it was always like that.
In 1993, isn't it correct that at that time, the conflict had died down, even though there was still enmity between IFP and ANC?
No, it is not correct.  The truth is there was enmity and there were conflicts.
Well Mr Mtambo, according to my instructions, by the time, by 1993, there wasn't political conflict between IFP and ANC, even though before, there was.  What do you have to say about that?
I don't understand your question Ms Thabete.  Are you saying that there was no enmity between the ANC and the IFP and that there was no conflict?
There was enmity between IFP and ANC, but by 1993, the fighting had stopped?   What is your comment on that?
Okay.  What were the relations between you and Mr Phumayo, the deceased?  Did you talk to each other, or did you just know him?
I used to talk to him, in fact I have spoken to him about the violence at Davel.

We actually grew together, at the time he wasn't a participant in political organisations.
So you knew him quite well?
That is the question that Ms Thabete was trying to elicit from you.
When Duduza Qaba told you that you will be attacked, you have testified that he didn't mention any names, isn't that so?
When did she actually tell you that your life was under threat?   Maybe to help you, in relation to the death of Mr Phumayo, when did she tell you this?
He told me before I killed Mr Phumayo.  What Duduza told me, when he told me, Phumayo was still alive.
Was it two days before you killed him, was it a week before you killed him, was it a month before you killed him when you were told this?
On the same day when I killed, on the 29th.

So when you say in your application at number 9 A4, page 8, that you had received earlier on a tip to the effect that the deceased made a vow that if you could be eliminated, their organisation in their region, will have peace of mind, that is not correct?

That is correct.  But this is what he said, him, the deceased, not Duduza.
	This is what he told me.
Who told you that the deceased had said this then?

Yes, that is what his evidence is.  His evidence now is that the deceased told him that himself.
	When did he tell you this?

I met him as I was leaving Mthetwa's house.  I don't remember the day, but this was before I took a decision that I was going to kill him.  He was the one who told me first that if I were to be killed, ANC will gain more members.
Can you explain what you were doing at Maria Mthetwa's shibeen that day when the deceased was killed?
I was just sitting there and this is the place I used to frequent.
So what were you doing there at the shibeen, just briefly, if you were not drinking?

I was just sitting there with the people who were drinking.  Most of the time, this is the place I used to sit.  I used to frequent Maria's place, sometimes Saturday morning, I used to spend my time relaxing at her place.
	When you are there, you can actually see the school.

No, it is fine, I don't need to know to reason why you were there.
	Do you drink at all generally?
Okay, when you arrived at Maria Mthetwa's shibeen that day, did you have a gun with you?
Why did you have a gun with you?
To protect myself because the situation was bad.
You say you saw or maybe I should ask you, when you saw the deceased, where were you, were you still at Maria's shibeen?
Yes, I was inside her house.

Which version is the true, were you at Maria's place or were you on your way home when you actually saw Mr Phumayo?
If I can explain there, when I left Maria's house, I was going home.
So what are you saying, were you on your way home, or were you still at Maria's place when you saw it, that is what I am trying to find out?
Can I explain what Ms Thabete is trying to find out from you, at page 30 I have got a typed record, whose handwriting is this Mr Mtambo, is this your handwriting?
No, it is not my handwriting.
Who wrote the statement for you?
Who is Alson?  Who is he?
He came to visit me in prison.
No, he said he was sent there by the TRC to take the statement.

He is the Investigator from the TRC.  Now what is contained here is that, paragraph 3, is that you only noticed Mr Phumayo as you were on your way home.  You only noticed him once you were out of Maria's house.
	During your viva voce evidence, you stated that you noticed him whilst you were inside the house, and you saw him standing next to an electric box.  That is not what is in your statement.  All that she wants you to explain is that difference.  Do you understand?

If I may explain, there are two streets.  I was sitting in Maria's house and peeping through the window, I was right inside the house.
	He was coming, because it was bright, because of the street lamps.  I saw him as he was coming.  Before he arrived at the electric box, that is when I came out from Maria's house and I said I am leaving for home because I didn't know exactly who was going to attack me.

I don't think you are answering her question.  She wants to know why in your statement you said you only noticed him as you were on your way home, whereas in your oral evidence, you say you saw him whilst you were inside the house?
I am trying to explain the difference.  I saw him for the first time while I was still inside the house, and when I was outside, I could see him as well.
We know that.  Are you saying therefore that what is contained in your statement, is incorrect?
I will say it is a lie.
Did you legal representative read this statement to you before the commencement of this hearing?
And did you notice that according to what is contained herein, the point at which you first saw Mr Mshenga was when you were on your way home and not when you were inside Maria's house?
No, I didn't notice that.  As I am explaining that there is a street right above Maria's house, and I thought this two were not conflicting each other that much.
Did you notice that your statement contained something that you did not agree with, that is my question, in relation to at what stage you saw Mshenga on the day in question?
Thank you Madam Chair.  Did you know where Mr Phumayo lived, his home?
How far was it from Maria's place?
It was far, much too far.  I think if I may count the streets, it is approximately five streets from Maria's place to his house.
My instructions are that when you actually saw Mr Phumayo, he was from his home.  What is your comment on that and he was very much close from his house or his home?
Are your instructions that Mr Phumayo's house was not five streets away from Maria's house?  Are those your instructions?
I will have to clarify that Madam Chair.
Mr Mtambo, you say when you followed the deceased, you actually caught up with him, is that correct?
And you say you had a conversation with him, is that correct?
Exactly what was the conversation, can you briefly tell us?
I greeted him and he greeted me back.  What I have noticed is that he was scared when I came closer to him.
Why did he show fear because I thought earlier on you said he was a very brave man and you were used to him, why would he fear you all of a sudden?

What I can say is that we were scared of each other, we were scared of meeting each other at night.
	That is why he was scared, because we never used to come closer to each other at night.

No, that is not my question.  My question is earlier on you testified to the fact that you were on good relations, you used to talk to each other and on this particular day, you just greeted him, and he had fear.  Why?

I don't know why he was scared.
And then, what was the conversation, what did he say to you, what did you say to him, if at all you did say anything to each other before you actually shot him?

He said we can walk along, and I asked him as to how can we walk along together, because he was an ANC member and I was an IFP member.
	There was no harmony between the two of us.  The reason I said so was because I didn't want other IFP members to think that I was betraying them, because they were going to think that I was betraying them.
Is that all you said to him, and what he said to you and then you shot him?
I can't remember what he said, other things he said.
Can you tell us how you shot him?  What led to you shooting him?

Sorry, if I can interrupt.  He hasn't answered your question, which you put to him, and you are just proceeding on.  You asked him is that all he said to you, not what you may have spoken about?  Your answer was, I can't remember everything I said to him.
	Did he say anything more to you besides let's go for a walk together?

I can't remember.  I can't remember if he added on that.
	Maybe it is because when I arrived there, I actually saw a chance that I should use that chance, to kill him.

The decision which I have already taken, wasn't specific to kill him, but the decision which I had taken was that I was going to kill anyone who belonged to ANC members.

	That is not what you initially said.  In your evidence in chief, you stated categorically that you yourself, took a decision to kill Phumayo, not any other member of the ANC.  It was a decision to kill a specific person and that person was Phumayo.
